head.title: On This First Day, a Fanfare for the New Era; Merely a Human Idea

hedline.hl1: On This First Day, a Fanfare for the New Era; Merely a Human Idea

abstract.p: Richard Palmer letter says humankind has not accomplished nearly enough to make the year 2000 worth celebrating; drawing

block.p: Joyce Carol Oates is not alone in her ''anemic response'' to the year 2000 (Op-Ed, Dec. 30). As a college biology instructor, I give my students the following lesson. The earth is about 4.5 billion years old. Dinosaurs dominated the earth for nearly 250 million of those years. In contrast, modern humans have been around for a mere 200,000 to 300,000 years.

Joyce Carol Oates is not alone in her ''anemic response'' to the year 2000 (Op-Ed, Dec. 30). As a college biology instructor, I give my students the following lesson. The earth is about 4.5 billion years old. Dinosaurs dominated the earth for nearly 250 million of those years. In contrast, modern humans have been around for a mere 200,000 to 300,000 years.

We've accomplished much, but we have a long way to go: just look at the gross inadequacies of wealth and power distribution around the world. Any human construct like this millennium is only that: a mere construct and nothing to make a big deal about. When we are properly able to care for the sick, the hungry and the homeless, and our environment, then Homo sapiens will have something to celebrate.
